author: boston.com
title: Morning Sports Update: Red Sox direct Hanley Ramirez to lose 15 to 20 pounds - Sports
text:
Don Orsillo calls his last game with the Red Sox, Tom Brady addresses his unexpected mobility, and the Sox order Hanley Ramirez to lose weight.
Red Sox players honor Orsillo after final out of season: “After the final out of the last game of the season, Red Sox players stood outside the visitors’ dugout at Progressive Field in Cleveland and tipped their caps toward the press box to team broadcaster Don Orsillo.” ( MassLive.com )
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Hanley Ramirez directed to lose 15 to 20 pounds: “In the event that Hanley Ramirez is back with the Red Sox next season, he might look a little different.” ( Boston Herald )
Brady: Maybe my mobility ‘demoralizes’ defenses: “Because, a lot of times, look, they’re going, ‘Brady’s in the pocket, he’s just going to be five yards behind the center. Let’s just get to that spot,’ ” Brady said. “Now they get there, and we’re getting the ball out quick, and all of a sudden I hold onto it and we make a play. And maybe it demoralizes them a little bit.” ( CSNNE.com )
John Farrell, Torey Lovullo could make for problematic dugout: “Fair or unfair, in an effort to cover all possibilities, the Sox have unintentionally created a potential combustible dugout situation as they prepare to get back into contention in 2016.” ( The Boston Globe )
With Bill Belichick’s son Stephen, the apple hasn’t fallen far from the tree: “Like his father, Steve Belichick played lacrosse and football in college. And like his father, he was known more for his IQ than his athletic ability. When people noticed his last name on a jersey or a roster, lofty expectations followed. He had to live up to the challenge in high school and later at Rutgers. He impressed various coaches and peers along the way.” ( Providence Journal )
Patriots face injury-riddled Cowboys with limited passing offense: “With the New England Patriots on the bye, it was a chance to look ahead to their next opponent, the Dallas Cowboys. The following are some thoughts/notes on the Cowboys, with the Patriots in mind, from Dallas’ 26-20 overtime loss to the New Orleans Saints.” ( ESPNBoston.com )
Photo finish: The most lucrative contracts in Red Sox history
Previous -- of -- Next The Sox signed hitting machine Manny Ramirez at the end of the 2000 season, in the prime of his career, to an eight-year deal worth $160 million in 2001. Ramirez currently holds the richest contract in Red Sox history. CHIN, Barry Globe Staff Previous -- of -- Next The Red Sox landed first baseman Adrian Gonzalez in a blockbuster trade prior to the 2011 season, and proceeded to sign him to a seven-year, $154 million extension. Jared Wickerham Previous -- of -- Next Looking for a spark after a third-place finish in 2010, the Red Sox splurged on outfielder Carl Crawford. Crawford’s deal was for seven years and $142 million. Winslow Townson Previous -- of -- Next The Red Sox locked up second baseman Dustin Pedroia through 2021 with an eight-year extension signed during the 2013 season. The extension is worth $110 million. Chris Szagola Previous -- of -- Next The Red Sox signed “Panda” to a five-year, $95 million deal prior to the 2015 season, bringing one of the game’s top postseason hitters to Boston. Tony Gutierrez Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The Red Sox signed ace Pedro Martinez to a six-year, $72.5 million contact in 1997, at the time a record amount for a pitcher. When the team picked up a one-year, $17.5 million option for 2004, it brought the total to $90 million. WINSLOW TOWNSON Previous -- of -- Next Needing a middle of the order bat, Boston signed Hanley Ramirez, a former top Red Sox prospect, to a four-year deal worth $88 million (with a $22 million fifth-year option) prior to the 2015 season. Matt Rourke Previous -- of -- Next After trading for Rick Porcello following 2014’s last-place finish, the Red Sox extended the former Detroit Tiger’s contract for four years at $82.5 million, making him the highest paid pitcher in franchise history. Chris Szagola Previous -- of -- Next The Red Sox signed starting pitcher John Lackey to a five-year, $82.5 million deal prior to 2010. After a rough start to his career in Boston, he helped the Sox win the 2013 World Series. Michael Dwyer Previous -- of -- Next After a long, drawn-out process in the winter after the 2006 season, the Red Sox inked outfielder J.D. Drew to a five-year, $70 million contract. SHAUN BEST Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Boston signed Josh Beckett to a four-year extension worth $68 million during the 2010 season, but wound up “dumping” Beckett, Gonzalez, and Crawford’s salaries in a blockbuster trade with the Dodgers in 2012. LM Otero Previous -- of -- Next David Ortiz earned a big paycheck after his 2005 season, in which he hit .300, with 47 HRs and 148 RBIs. The club signed him to a four-year, $52 million extension through the 2010 season. Ronald Martinez Previous -- of -- Next Boston signed Daisuke Matsuzaka to a six-year, $52 million contract in 2006, not accounting for the $51.1 million posting fee they paid his Japanese team for exclusive negotiating rights. STEVE NESIUS
